issues.description: Template's Stock.findStockIngredient method signature takes two parameters (String name, boolean caseSensitive), but the problem statement's UML and the solution implementation expect a single-parameter method findStockIngredient(String). Additionally, the template's add(String) and take(String) methods call findStockIngredient with a single argument, which is incompatible with the two-parameter definition and will cause compilation errors and confusion for students. This mismatch prevents students from following the specified API and from compiling/running the provided template code.
issues.suggested_fix: Change the template Stock.findStockIngredient method to match the specification and solution by providing a single-parameter signature: public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name). Alternatively, add an overload public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name) that delegates to the existing two-parameter method (e.g., defaulting case sensitivity) so that existing calls in add/take compile. Ensure the template's add and take methods call the single-parameter variant to match the UML and solution.

issues.description: The problem statement (and the solution) refer to a Stock method findStockIngredient(String) while the template repository implements findStockIngredient(String, boolean). This is a signature / naming mismatch for the same conceptual operation (looking up a StockIngredient by name). Students reading the problem will expect a single-parameter method and may be confused when the template requires an extra boolean parameter (or when they try to call the one-argument form). The solution uses the one-argument form, so the template deviates from the expected API and creates an unnecessary mapping burden.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the template API with the problem statement and solution by providing a one-argument findStockIngredient(String) method. For example, add an overload in the template: public StockIngredient findStockIngredient(String name) { return findStockIngredient(name, true); } or change the template implementation to expose only the single-parameter method. This preserves the intended API in the problem and avoids confusion.
